finding: The BDNF Val66Met (rs6265) polymorphism was found to influence local oscillation amplitudes and is specifically implicated in the strength of large-scale synchronization of neuronal oscillations. This polymorphism was connected to variations in serotonin receptor binding and influenced the activity-dependent secretion of BDNF, thereby affecting neuronal circuit dynamics and inter-individual variability in cognition.
title: Genetic polymorphisms in COMT and BDNF influence synchronization dynamics of human neuronal oscillations

finding: The SNP rs11039471 was identified with a significant association with nightmares, evidenced by a p-value of 3.7e-8. It was located intronically to the PTPRJ gene, which had previously been associated with sleep duration. This discovery highlighted a possible genetic correlation between nightmare frequency and disturbed sleep traits.
title: Nightmares share strong genetic risk with sleep and psychiatric disorders

finding: The rs4930155 variant was identified as a eQTL specific to treated CD8+ T cells, showing strong colocalization with a Crohn’s disease GWAS locus. BAD, the gene associated with this variant, encodes a pro-apoptotic Bcl-2 protein and plays a role in CD8+ T cell functional regulation.
title: Systemic CD8+ T cell effector signature predicts prognosis of lung cancer immunotherapy

finding: The variant rs1199047 is strongly linked with rs4930155 and shows significant colocalizations with Crohn's disease GWAS locus, suggesting a connection in immune response regulation.
title: Systemic CD8+ T cell effector signature predicts prognosis of lung cancer immunotherapy

finding: The SNP rs12252-C, a variant in the Interferon-induced transmembrane protein-3 (IFITM3), was associated with severe influenza in Chinese individuals. This genetic variant highlighted the importance of IFITM3 in modulating the severity of influenza infections, potentially influencing the inflammatory response and subsequent cardiac complications related to influenza virus infection.
title: Influenza virus replication in cardiomyocytes drives heart dysfunction and fibrosis

finding: Similar to rs2764450, this SNP was noted for antisocial behavior and maintained the same direction of effect. Nonetheless, like rs2764450, it also failed to show a significant association with AGGall due to a P value greater than 0.5.
title: Genetic Association Study of Childhood Aggression across raters, instruments and age

finding: The SNP rs11604261 was associated with variation in DAGLα expression in the brain. This variation suggested that individual differences in this locus could influence susceptibility to alcohol use disorder (AUD) and may serve as a biomarker for predicting how individuals might respond to pharmacological inhibition of diacylglycerol lipase (DAGL). Thus, it highlighted the significance of genetic variants in understanding behavioral and treatment outcomes related to AUD.
title: Targeting Diacylglycerol Lipase to Reduce Alcohol Consumption

finding: The SNP was identified as a functional genetic variant, consistent with its prior classification as a 'conditional SNP' for major depressive disorder (MDD). This supports the presence of multiple functional SNPs within GWAS loci.
title: Transcriptional-Regulatory Convergence Across Functional MDD Risk Variants Identified by Massively Parallel Reporter Assays

finding: This SNP perturbed RXRA motifs and was identified as a functional variant in human retinoid pathways, suggesting its importance in MDD-associated regulatory mechanisms.
title: Transcriptional-Regulatory Convergence Across Functional MDD Risk Variants Identified by Massively Parallel Reporter Assays

finding: The SNP rs2276138 was identified as a lead genetic variant associated with major depressive disorder (MDD). It resided within an intronic region of the SPTBN2 gene, where it disrupted a binding site for the transcription factor RFX3. This alteration in binding was linked to changes in chromatin accessibility in deep-layer excitatory neurons, which were shown to be enriched for MDD-associated genetic variation impacting synaptic communication pathways.
title: Differential Chromatin Architecture and Risk Variants in Deep Layer Excitatory Neurons and Grey Matter Microglia Contribute to Major Depressive Disorder

finding: The SNP rs11601579 was found to disrupt binding site accessibility for the transcription factor GLI2, associated with neurodevelopment. It overlapped with cCREs related to the SHANK2 gene, a known participant in neuropsychiatric disorders, and exhibited a significant correlation with anti-sense RNA expression of SHANK2, indicating its regulatory importance.
title: Differential Chromatin Architecture and Risk Variants in Deep Layer Excitatory Neurons and Grey Matter Microglia Contribute to Major Depressive Disorder

finding: The SNP rs33918474, which results in a p.Val20Glu change in human β-haemoglobin, was identified as causing erythrocytosis. This variant is a non-synonymous missense mutation that alters the amino acid from valine to glutamic acid at position 20. In contrast, the equivalent amino acid change is wild type in horse β-haemoglobin, suggesting a compensatory interaction with another amino acid change at position 69 (His in horse vs. Gly in human). This finding emphasized the importance of considering variant-variant interactions in understanding the functional consequences of SNPs.
title: Individual human genomes frequently contain variants that have epistatic interactions

finding: The SNP rs3842753 was found to be associated with increased β-cell INS mRNA levels in a comprehensive meta-analysis of single-cell RNA-sequencing data, indicating its potential role in influencing beta-cell function related to type 1 diabetes risk. This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic factors affecting pancreatic β-cell dynamics.
title: Sex differences in islet stress responses support female beta cell resilience

finding: The SNP rs11040587 was identified as having a significant role in regulating cell migration, proliferation, and survival in glioblastoma. This finding was derived from a study that highlighted its association with the function of Integrin alpha 10, indicating that this SNP could serve as a novel therapeutic target in glioblastoma, which is critical for understanding therapeutic approaches aimed at improving survival rates.
title: Glioblastoma cells use an integrin- and CD44-mediated motor-clutch mode of migration in brain tissue

finding: It received the highest score in its risk locus, surpassing GWAS SNP rs77502336 related to schizophrenia.
title: WEVar: a novel statistical learning framework for predicting noncoding regulatory variants

finding: Furthermore, rs4944014 was found to be significantly linked to both MS and CD, thereby supporting the evidence for genetic connections between these disorders.
title: Investigating the shared genetic architecture between multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel diseases

finding: The SNP rs646153 was identified as a novel locus associated with MS and CD, indicating shared genetic pathways that may affect the pathophysiology of both conditions.
title: Investigating the shared genetic architecture between multiple sclerosis and inflammatory bowel diseases

finding: The SNP rs163184, located in the KCNQ1 gene, was identified as being associated with Type 2 Diabetes. It was found to modulate the binding activity of transcription factors Sp3 and Lsd1/Kdm1a, which potentially affects the expression of the CDKN1C gene. These findings suggested a mechanism through which the SNP could contribute to the pathophysiology of Type 2 Diabetes via alterations in insulin secretion.
title: AFF3 and BACH2 are master regulators of metabolic inflexibility, β/α-cell transition, and dedifferentiation in type 2 diabetes

finding: The G allele of rs2513280 was associated with increased alcohol consumption among women in an analysis of the UK Biobank, where the association was statistically significant (p=0.0463), having been analyzed in a large cohort of 345,140 individuals. In men, this association was not significant (p=0.478). The study also demonstrated a significant interaction between anxiety and the G allele in male participants, linking increased alcohol consumption and anxiety.
title: CRISPR disruption and UK Biobank analysis of a highly conserved polymorphic enhancer suggests a role in male anxiety and ethanol intake

finding: The SNP rs596002 was replicated in the independent cohort as a significant deQTL for CTSW in CD8 cells. It showed a consistent association with gene expression variability.
title: Genetic variants associated with cell-type-specific intra-individual gene expression variability reveal new mechanisms of genome regulation

finding: The study provided evidence that the SNP rs12807809, associated with neuropsychological functioning in schizophrenia, correlated with impaired long-term potentiation (LTP) in synapses that express GluR1 receptors. Specifically, alterations in the expression levels of genes regulating plasticity due to genetic factors were implicated in the observed LTP deficits, suggesting a mechanism through which schizophrenia manifests impaired cortical plasticity.
title: Genetic mechanisms for impaired synaptic plasticity in schizophrenia revealed by computational modelling

finding: This SNP was linked to two traits in opposite directions, exemplifying its complex influence on phenotypic traits.
title: Multivariate Genomewide Association Analysis with IHT

finding: The rs34481144 SNP was associated with severe outcomes following Influenza A virus infection and severe COVID-19. It was part of findings suggesting that defects in IFITM3 contribute to reduced cell-intrinsic immunity, thereby affecting susceptibility to infections such as SARS-CoV-2.
title: Rapalogs downmodulate intrinsic immunity and promote cell entry of SARS-CoV-2

finding: The rs12252 SNP was linked to severe outcomes in COVID-19 and Influenza A virus infections. The finding highlighted that IFITM3 loss-of-function due to this SNP may compromise the antiviral response, increasing susceptibility to viral infections.
title: Rapalogs downmodulate intrinsic immunity and promote cell entry of SARS-CoV-2

finding: The rs174549 polymorphism in FADS1 was reported to potentially predict a favorable response to chemoradiotherapy in oral cancer patients. This finding suggested that the genetic variant may have implications for treatment outcomes, although its direct association with triple receptor negative breast cancer (TNBC) was not explicitly stated in the provided text.
title: Identification of Key Genes Potentially Related to Triple Receptor Negative Breast Cancer by Microarray Analysis

finding: The SNP rs10830963, located in the <italic>MTNR1B</italic> gene, was associated with diurnal serum glucose levels, showing a robust temporal association with P = 1e-22. This variant was found to both influence insulin secretion and increase fasting glucose levels, contributing to a heightened risk of type 2 diabetes (T2DM). Moreover, the effect sizes varied throughout the day, demonstrating a more significant impact in the morning. This finding was replicated in a separate cohort, the Estonian Biobank, confirming opposite effects on glucose levels between morning (beta = 0.076, P = 1e-13) and evening (beta = -0.021, P = 0.03).
title: Genetic variants affect diurnal glucose levels throughout the day

finding: The SNP rs12419690, found in the <italic>CRY2</italic> gene, also exhibited a strong association with diurnal glucose levels, with a noted significance of P = 1e-16. While it was identified as having a role in moderating glucose levels independently, its association showed high heterogeneity in effect sizes across different times of the day. The morning effect was replicated with a beta of 0.022 and P = 2e-8, whereas an evening effect was not replicated. Thus, it was established that <italic>CRY2</italic> also functions as a temporal regulator of glucose metabolism.
title: Genetic variants affect diurnal glucose levels throughout the day

finding: The SNP rs4938344 was identified as an eQTL regulating the long non-coding RNA AP000892.6. The reference allele G resulted in decreased expression of AP000892.6, as observed in both GTEx data and caffeine treatment conditions. This SNP was associated with increased risk for conditions like CAD and hypertension due to its impact on gene regulation, particularly through the binding of transcription factors ETV1 and GABP, which were upregulated by caffeine exposure.
title: Characterization of caffeine response regulatory variants in vascular endothelial cells

finding: The SNP rs10833823 demonstrated enhanced recruitment of cofactors TBL1XR1, GCN5, and RBBP5 at the SNP allele compared to the reference allele in myeloid cells, yet did not alter TF binding, indicating a mechanism of altered COF recruitment, potentially involving DNA allostery.
title: Customizable high-throughput platform for profiling cofactor recruitment to DNA to characterize cis-regulatory elements and screen non-coding single-nucleotide polymorphisms

finding: The SNP rs11040529 showed positive associations with melanoma progression and aggression conditions, reinforcing the role of MIF in the tumor microenvironment, and highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target in melanoma treatments.
title: Temporal genomic analysis of melanoma rejection identifies regulators of tumor immune evasion

finding: At the TH locus, rs4929965 was identified as a beta-cell specific open chromatin region containing three putative causal variants. It significantly contacted the INS promoter over 12kb in beta cells, indicating its critical role in diabetes pathogenesis.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: This SNP was implicated at the T2D TH locus and was part of an open chromatin region that interacted with TRPM5 in both alpha and beta cells, suggesting it played a role in the regulatory mechanism of T2D.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: Also located at the TH locus, rs4929964 was shown to engage in chromatin looping to the INS promoter in beta cells, highlighting its relevance to the regulatory architecture involved in diabetes risk.
title: The three-dimensional chromatin structure of the major human pancreatic cell types reveals lineage-specific regulatory architecture of T2D risk

finding: The DRD2/ANKK1 TaqIA A1 allele (rs1800497) was associated with diminished learning performance in response inhibition tasks aimed at obtaining rewards in three independent cohorts. A1 carriers, when compared to A2 homozygotes, showed marked differences in learning and motivational behaviors, reinforcing the significant role of this SNP in dopaminergic neurotransmission and decision-making processes.
title: Motivational learning biases are differentially modulated by genetic determinants of striatal and prefrontal dopamine function

finding: The rs3842770 SNP in the INS-IGF2 locus was replicated in this study with a p-value of 1.867 × 10^-3, demonstrating its association with T2D among the studied populations.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: The rs4072825 SNP associated with the TH-INS locus was found to be genome-wide significant (p=2.35 × 10^-8) in this analysis, emphasizing its role in T2D risk assessment.
title: A Novel Type 2 Diabetes Locus in sub-Saharan Africans, ZRANB3, is Implicated in Beta Cell Proliferation

finding: The SNP rs11042811 was identified as an eQTL for AMPD3, suggesting a role in oligodendrocyte involvement in white matter microstructure.
title: Brain expression quantitative trait locus and network analysis reveals downstream effects and putative drivers for brain-related diseases

finding: The SNP rs2303865 was associated with the gene CD82, which is implicated in oligodendrocyte-related pathways.
title: Brain expression quantitative trait locus and network analysis reveals downstream effects and putative drivers for brain-related diseases

finding: The study confirmed that ZNF148 displayed differential binding to the rs509813 major SNP, implicating it in the regulation of the TERT gene based on its binding to the proximal promoter sequence.
title: E4F1 and ZNF148 are transcriptional activators of the A57C and wildtype TERT promoter

finding: Identified as an exonic variant in the HMBS gene, rs1131488 showed significant voxel-wise associations in thalamic regions, implicating it in disorders like acute intermittent porphyria and leukoencephalopathy, as seen through MRI anomalies.
title: Phenotypic and genetic associations of quantitative magnetic susceptibility in UK Biobank brain imaging

finding: This SNP, associated with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) levels in sickle cell anemia, demonstrated a strong selection signal in African (AFR), American (AMR), and European (EUR) populations, exemplifying balancing selection associated with a disease.
title: Improved detection of evolutionary selection highlights potential bias from different sequencing strategies in complex genomic-regions

finding: The Alt protective allele of rs12275749 at the CCND1 locus was discovered to disrupt the SMAD3 binding motif and was associated with reduced cell growth in MCF7 cells. This finding related to the TGFβ-SMAD3 signaling pathway, which is known to decrease the number of mammosphere-initiating cells.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: The Alt protective allele rs12275479 (T>C) at the CCND1 locus was linked to reduced cell growth. It disrupted a SMAD3 binding motif, indicating a role in modulating the TGFβ-SMAD3 pathway and its effects on mammosphere-initiating cells.
title: High throughput PRIME editing screens identify functional DNA variants in the human genome

finding: This SNP was noted for its relevance in the heterogeneity of circulating tumor cells, specifically focusing on the stem-cell subset.
title: Propagated circulating tumor cells uncovers the role of NFκB and COP1 in metastasis

finding: A signal of moderate selection was found at the TYR locus by SIA, with a selection probability of 0.62 and a selection coefficient of about 0.0011, implying its significance in pigmentation traits.
title: SIA: Selection Inference Using the Ancestral Recombination Graph

finding: KCNJ11 gene polymorphism rs5219 was associated with an increased risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus, indicating a significant genetic factor in the disease's etiology.
title: Bioinformatics analysis of potential key genes and mechanisms in type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The rs1042602(A) allele, associated with pigmentation, was studied for its spatiotemporal dynamics in Western Eurasia and demonstrated signs of recent selection in history. Estimates indicated a selection coefficient of 0.0221 before 5,000 years ago, which decreased to 0.0102 after this period, suggesting a decline in selection pressure over time. The allele's geographic origin was inferred to correspond with areas where it initially segregated between 7,500 and 10,000 years ago, indicating a major influence on the allele's distribution driven by historical population dynamics.
title: Modelling the spatiotemporal spread of beneficial alleles using ancient genomes

finding: The SNP rs1453541 was found to be significantly associated with Galaxolide intensity perception, showing strong correlation in both the discovery cohort (p<2.07×10⁻²⁵) and the validation cohort (p<9.08×10⁻⁶). This finding was considered novel and added to the understanding of olfactory receptor activity.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs1453542 was also associated with Galaxolide intensity perception, replicating associations in both cohorts (discovery p<2.59×10⁻²⁵, validation p<1.02×10⁻⁵). This was another novel finding related to this musk receptor.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs3898917 was significantly linked with the perception of 3M2H, showing associations in the discovery cohort (p<1.20×10⁻¹¹) and confirmed in the validation cohort (p<7.89×10⁻⁵), representing a novel discovery in the olfactory genetics.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs6591536 was strongly associated with β-ionone intensity perception in both cohorts (discovery p<1.84×10⁻⁴¹, validation p<7.80×10⁻³⁹). This SNP was previously reported and provided strong evidence for its role in olfactory perception.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs7941591 was also associated with Galaxolide intensity in the validation cohort (p<5.8×10⁻⁶), reinforcing the novel findings surrounding the musk receptor associations with odor perception.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The SNP rs10837814 was associated with the perception of 3M2H in both the discovery (p<6.57×10⁻¹⁰) and validation cohorts (p<9.60×10⁻⁸), providing significant evidence of its role in olfactory perception.
title: From musk to body odor: decoding olfaction through genetic variation

finding: The index SNP rs2176598 was recognized as a candidate regulator, linked with gene HSD17B12, contributing to L1 expression regulation, although specific findings regarding gene set changes were not detailed.
title: A Computational Approach for the Identification of Novel L1 Transcriptional Regulators

finding: At the MS4A locus, rs636317 showed a significant effect, as both monocyte and microglia models predicted it as an outlier. This variant was linked to allelic imbalance in myeloid cells, indicating it disrupted a CTCF transcription factor binding site and reduced regulatory activity, consistent with findings from previous studies.
title: Regression convolutional neural network models implicate peripheral immune regulatory variants in the predisposition to Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The study indicated that the BDNF Val66Met (rs6265) polymorphism was associated with persistent changes in synaptic function following isoflurane exposure. Specifically, carriers of this SNP exhibited reduced hippocampal volume, altered synaptic plasticity, and impaired learning and memory. This SNP was implicated in the reduction of vesicular BDNF release, leading to transient depression of excitatory synaptic transmission.
title: A common human brain-derived neurotrophic factor polymorphism leads to sustained depression of excitatory synaptic transmission by isoflurane in hippocampus

finding: The study found that the genotype at SNP rs2071094 was associated with the methylation levels of CpG3 in the CTCF6 region of the H19 gene. Analysis showed that individuals with the TT genotype had significantly lower methylation levels compared to those with the AT or AA genotypes. This association was observed across both normal controls (NC) and normally methylated infertile (NMI) patients, indicating that genetic variation influenced methylation levels regardless of fertility status.
title: The sperm epigenome does not display recurrent epimutations in patients with severely impaired spermatogenesis

finding: The SNP rs3740688 had a significant association with Alzheimer's disease (AD), demonstrating an odds ratio of 0.92 with a meta-analysis p-value of 5.4 x 10^-13. This study encompassed a large population of 35,274 AD cases compared to 59,163 controls, indicating that genetic variants at this locus could lower AD risk.
title: Modest changes in Spi1 dosage reveal the potential for altered microglial function as seen in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The variant rs1057233 was associated with an increased expression of SPI1, suggesting it could lead to an earlier age of onset for Alzheimer's Disease. This finding highlighted the role of SPI1 in the regulation of gene expression related to AD risk.
title: Modest changes in Spi1 dosage reveal the potential for altered microglial function as seen in Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs6589566 was associated with triglycerides (TG) in this study, demonstrating a genome-wide significant finding with <italic>P</italic><sub>D</sub> = 3.98 × 10<sup>−18</sup>.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: SNP rs3741298 was significantly associated with total cholesterol (TC) at <italic>P</italic><sub>D</sub> = 1.63 × 10<sup>−7</sup>.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: The variant rs964184 near APOA1 showed a significant association with total cholesterol (TC), confirming its role in lipid metabolism with findings from the Samoan cohort.
title: Genome-wide association studies in Samoans give insight into the genetic architecture of fasting serum lipid levels.

finding: The presence of the Val66Met (rs6265) SNP served as a critical determinant in auditory neuroplasticity among musicians. In the study, Val/Val carriers exhibited enhanced brain responses to prediction errors during auditory processing compared to Met carriers and non-musicians. This finding indicated that genetic variations in BDNF significantly influenced neural adaptations resulting from long-term musical training.
title: BDNF Val66Met polymorphism as putative genetic substrate of music-induced plasticity in auditory prediction

finding: The SNP rs1061810 was significantly associated with HSD17B12 gene expression across all twelve tissues studied. It showed a negative NES of -0.64 (P <= 4.86·10^-19), suggesting a considerable impact on the fatty acid synthesis process.
title: Understanding functional consequences of type 2 diabetes risk loci using the universal data integration and visualization R package CONQUER

finding: The missense mutation at position rs61742524 (Cys3Trp) was linked to polyspermy, an abnormal fertilization phenomenon. It was present in 3 out of 330 females with polyspermy, but not found in any of 300 matching controls during IVF studies.
title: Genetic Diversity in the IZUMO1-JUNO Protein-Receptor Pair Involved in Human Reproduction

finding: The FADS2 gene rs174583 polymorphism was found to impact desaturase activities, fatty acid profile, insulin resistance, biochemical indices, and the incidence of type 2 diabetes, indicating its role in metabolic processes related to T2DM.
title: Analysis of key genes and pathways associated with the pathogenesis of Type 2 diabetes mellitus

finding: The SNP rs10792832 was identified as the lead colocalized SNP for the gene PICALM in microglia, demonstrating a significant association with Alzheimer's disease (AD). This SNP colocalized with a microglial-specific enhancer and was connected to the promoter region of PICALM, indicating its role in the regulation of PICALM expression in a cell-type specific context related to AD.
title: Single-cell Mendelian randomisation identifies cell-type specific genetic effects on human brain disease and behaviour

finding: The SNP rs2232950 was identified as a common missense variant in SCGB1D2, changing proline to leucine at position 53. It was predicted to be deleterious and showed a strong association with Lyme disease, with a P value of 1.82×10^-24, reinforcing its role as a host defense factor against Bb infection.
title: Secretoglobin family 1D member 2 (SCGB1D2) protein inhibits growth of Borrelia burgdorferi and affects susceptibility to Lyme disease

finding: The variant rs4110197 was marked as the strongest association for Lyme disease at the SCGB1D2 locus, with a P value of 2.95×10^-25. It was indicated as an intronic variant, and its relationship with the missense variant rs2232950 was noted, demonstrating the critical genetic variation related to Lyme disease susceptibility.
title: Secretoglobin family 1D member 2 (SCGB1D2) protein inhibits growth of Borrelia burgdorferi and affects susceptibility to Lyme disease

finding: SNP rs10742814 was associated with the DrinksPerWeek phenotype, although a specific p-value was not provided. This SNP was noted to have predicted cell-type specific activity in medium spiny neurons (MSNs).
title: Addiction-associated genetic variants implicate brain cell type- and region-specific cis-regulatory elements in addiction neurobiology

finding: The SNP rs2773516 was associated with heteroplasmic burden in European Americans, presenting a significance level of p=7.1E-10, with a minor allele frequency of 0.40. This variant explained 1.3% of the variability in heteroplasmy burden, indicating its potential role in impacting mitochondrial DNA mutations within this population.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs36145545 was found to be significantly associated with heteroplasmic burden in African Americans, with a p-value of 9.4E-11 and a minor allele frequency of 0.38. This SNP accounted for 1.2% of the variability in heteroplasmy burden, highlighting its relevance in mitochondrial function in the African American cohort.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: In meta-analysis of both European and African American populations, rs779031139 emerged with an exceptionally low p-value of 2.0e-18, suggesting a strong association with heteroplasmic burden. This SNP contributed to an explanation of 3.5% of interindividual variation in the heteroplasmic burden among European Americans and 3.6% among African Americans.
title: Presence and Transmission of Mitochondrial Heteroplasmic Mutations in Human Populations of European and African Ancestry

finding: The SNP rs174557 was found to be down-regulated by the PATZ1 protein, which bound to this SNP and affected the expression of FADS1. This interaction was diminished by SP1/SREBP1c, suggesting a regulatory network that influences adipogenesis and lipid metabolism. This finding highlighted the role of PATZ1 in modulating key genes associated with lipid storage and metabolic processes in adipose tissues.
title: Transcriptional control of adipogenesis by PATZ1

finding: The SNP rs10835638 revealed a significant association in the 11p14.1 FSHB locus with P_meta=4.94×10^-12 and was genetically significant in the indeterminate subgroup.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs10835646 also showed a significant association within the FSHB locus with P_meta=2.75×10^-11, indicating relevance to indeterminate PCOS cases.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs11031006 was associated with indeterminate PCOS cases, with P_meta=2.96×10^-10, and was in linkage disequilibrium with rs10835638.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs11031005 was also significantly associated with the indeterminate subgroup (P_meta=2.91×10^-10) and in linkage disequilibrium with the lead SNP in the FSHB locus.
title: Phenotypic clustering reveals distinct subtypes of polycystic ovary syndrome with novel genetic associations

finding: The SNP rs112369934, located on chromosome 11 near the TRIM66 gene, was identified as a novel locus associated with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) in a large cohort of African Americans. It reached genome-wide significance with a p-value of 2.01 x 10^-8 and an adjusted odds ratio of 1.67, indicating a potential risk factor for the disease.
title: Genome wide-association study identifies novel loci in the Primary Open-Angle African American Glaucoma Genetics (POAAGG) study

finding: This loss of function mutation in the APOC3 gene was associated with lower triglyceride levels and identified a novel relationship with increased HDL-C levels in individuals carrying the A allele.
title: Role of Rare and Low Frequency Variants in Gene-Alcohol Interactions on Plasma Lipid Levels

finding: The rs231361 variant at the KCNQ1 locus was identified as a causal variant for type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk, showing effects on an enhancer that had long-range co-accessibility to the insulin promoter in beta cells. Its deletion resulted in reduced insulin gene and protein expression in human embryonic stem cell-derived beta cells.
title: Single cell chromatin accessibility reveals pancreatic islet cell type- and state-specific regulatory programs of diabetes risk

finding: This SNP interrupted the binding of transcription factor REST, which specifically regulated the gene GAB2 in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
title: Integrative analysis of multi-omics reveals gene regulatory networks across brain regions from risk variants to phenotypes of Alzheimer’s disease and Covid-19

finding: The sSNP rs11382548 affected splicing for the TMEM216 gene, specifically influencing intron excisions. It was shown to create a canonical splice site, impacting the expression of transcripts relevant to neurogenesis.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: Identified as a progenitor-specific sSNP, rs1222218 was linked to an alternative exon skipping for ARL14EP and colocalized with a schizophrenia GWAS index SNP, showing the role of this variant in neuronal development.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The SNP rs1765142 was noted for its connection with a novel exon skipping splicing event for ARL14EP and coalesced with the SCZ index SNP rs1222218, highlighting its importance in neurodevelopmental impact related to schizophrenia.
title: Genetic influences on cell type specific gene expression and splicing during neurogenesis elucidate regulatory mechanisms of brain traits

finding: The rs12252-C SNP was associated with an increased risk for severe influenza virus infection, particularly in the Chinese population, where it was found to be homozygous in 20% of individuals. This SNP was suggested to cause mislocalization of IFITM3, leading to an inability to effectively inhibit influenza virus infections, marking it as a significant genetic variant tied to severe outcomes from influenza.
title: IFITM3 protects the heart during influenza virus infection

finding: The rs34481144-A SNP, located in the promoter of the IFITM3 gene, was noted to be homozygous in 4% of individuals with European ancestry. This genetic variant was linked to lower levels of IFITM3 production, rendering carriers more susceptible to influenza virus infections, highlighting its role in influencing disease severity.
title: IFITM3 protects the heart during influenza virus infection

finding: This rare African-specific noncoding variant was associated with the APOA gene cluster and serum levels of apolipoproteins, highlighting its importance in serum biomarker studies.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: This noncoding variant linked to the sickle cell trait showed associations with cystatin C, contributing to the understanding of kidney function in African ancestry populations.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The variant rs111709242 in PPFIBP2 was predicted to be deleterious and was significant for its role in synapse formation and NMJ functionality, linking to CMS through its network connections with other known CMS-related genes.
title: Rare disease research workflow using multilayer networks elucidates the molecular determinants of severity in Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes

finding: SNP rs77975665 also affected PPFIBP2, contributing to synaptic development and was identified as a deleterious variant within the CMS context, showcasing its potential impact on disease severity.
title: Rare disease research workflow using multilayer networks elucidates the molecular determinants of severity in Congenital Myasthenic Syndromes

finding: The SNP rs6265 was associated with decreased blood levels of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) in schizophrenia patients. This finding linked the genotype of rs6265 to alterations in BDNF levels, which are implicated in the pathology of schizophrenia, highlighting the significance of genetic variations in neuropsychiatric conditions.
title: A marker chromosome in psychosis identifies glycine decarboxylase (GLDC) as a novel regulator of neuronal and synaptic function in the hippocampus

finding: The SNP rs174593 was examined as a potential causal variant for reduced LDL cholesterol levels. The C allele of this variant was shown to enhance the binding of the ELK1 transcription factor, resulting in increased FADS2 expression. Given that higher FADS2 expression correlates with reduced LDL cholesterol levels, the C allele may exert a protective effect against atherosclerosis by decreasing LDL levels.
title: Deciphering regulatory DNA sequences and noncoding genetic variants using neural network models of massively parallel reporter assays

finding: The rs664589 polymorphism in the MALAT1 gene had been shown to inhibit binding to miR-194-5p, which contributed to an increased risk of colorectal cancer, as well as its growth and metastasis. This finding was particularly significant as it highlighted the role of the MALAT1 gene in oncogenic processes.
title: Loss of Lamin A leads to the nuclear translocation of AGO2 and compromised RNA interference

finding: The SNP rs174549 tagged the primary haplotype in the gene FADS1, which was established as a selected haplotype. The significance of the selection signals suggested that the regulation of FADS1 impacted fitness, affecting the expression of nearby genes like FEN1 and FADS3, which were considered side-effects rather than direct causes of selection.
title: A gene-level test for directional selection on gene expression

finding: The study found a novel association between the minor allele (G) of rs7937515 and decreased network segregation measures, specifically clustering coefficient and local efficiency, in the left middle temporal gyrus. This genetic effect was consistent across both young and elderly adults, indicating that rs7937515 may be a significant genetic marker for variations in brain connectivity over the lifespan.
title: Genetic Influence underlying Brain Connectivity Phenotype: A Study on Two Age-Specific Cohorts

finding: The SNP rs662799 located in the ZPR1-APOA5 region was found to elevate triglyceride levels, showing a strong positive correlation with higher triglyceride levels in the Jomon people, an adaptation potentially linked to sustaining energy for thermogenesis.
title: Cold adaptation in Upper Paleolithic hunter-gatherers of eastern Eurasia

finding: This SNP was established as a joint lead risk SNP for both vitiligo and melanoma, affirming significant association and shared genetic factors related to these conditions.
title: Autoimmune Alleles at the Major Histocompatibility Locus Modify Melanoma Susceptibility

finding: The minor allele (A) of the driver variant rs74911261 was associated with lower telomere length, showing an average decrease of 80.4 base pairs per allele. Additionally, this allele exhibited a consistent effect direction across datasets, despite not being replicated in the KDELC2 testing. Importantly, rs74911261's A allele was previously linked to a decreased risk of breast cancer and an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma in individuals of European ancestry, highlighting its relevance in telomere biology and cancer risk.
title: Novel genetic determinants of telomere length from a multi-ethnic analysis of 75,000 whole genome sequences in TOPMed

finding: The study associated the FADS1 polymorphism (rs174537) with immune cell profiles in abdominal and femoral subcutaneous adipose tissue among adults with obesity, suggesting its involvement in obesity-related immune responses.
title: Study on potential differentially expressed genes in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis by bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: This SNP was shown to significantly influence the number of cups of tea consumed per day and explained over 96% of the observed phenotypic variance of beta-ionone sensitivity, located on chromosome 11q12 with a P value of 3.1×10^-9.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: Associated with the number of cups of coffee consumed per day, this SNP was found in a distinct region on chromosome 11q12 and had a significance of P=1.1×10^-8.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: This SNP showed strong association with the type of spread used, specifically butter vs. any other spread, with a significance of P=9.1×10^-15 and is located in a region associated with olfactory receptor genes.
title: Comprehensive genomic analysis of dietary habits in UK Biobank identifies hundreds of genetic loci and establishes causal relationships between educational attainment and healthy eating

finding: The SNP rs11040564 was associated with tumor-associated neutrophils in cancer, highlighting its role in the immune environment of tumors. The study indicated that overactive NRF2 contributed to the elevation of neutrophil chemoattractants such as interleukin-8 (CXCL8) and ENA-78 (CXCL5), suggesting that this SNP could be linked to immunosuppressive neutrophil activity in NRF2-overactive cancer cells.
title: Pan-cancer scale screening reveals NRF2 associated immunoevasive characteristics in non-small cell lung cancer and squamous malignancies

finding: The SNP rs4937333 was identified as being located in the miRNA-5003-Binding Site of the ETS1 3' UTR. This SNP was associated with decreased expression of the ETS1 gene, which plays a crucial role in regulating immune responses. The findings suggested a connection between this specific genomic variation and the modulation of ETS1 expression, further emphasizing the importance of Ets1 gene regulation in immune cell functionality.
title: Sequences within and upstream of the mouse Ets1 gene drive high level expression in B cells, but are not sufficient for consistent expression in T cells

finding: The SNP rs35705950 was identified as a gain-of-function promoter variant for MUC5B, which significantly increased MUC5B expression and was associated with the occurrence of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). This variant accounted for at least 30% of the total risk of developing IPF and was consistently corroborated by multiple independent studies. Moreover, it was observed that individuals carrying the TT-minor allele had enhanced MUC5B mucus expression, both in unaffected subjects and in patients diagnosed with IPF.
title: Pulmonary Fibrosis Ferret Model Demonstrates Sustained Fibrosis, Restrictive Physiology, and Aberrant Repair

finding: The SNP rs11020145 was associated with calcium signaling pathways in brain cancers, specifically referencing its role in glioblastoma. The context of this finding highlighted the interaction of calcium cations with glioblastoma electrotaxis, particularly showing that T98G cells had an anodal electrotaxis dependence on extracellular calcium, which was fundamental to its biological behavior.
title: Voltage-gated ion channels mediate the electrotaxis of glioblastoma cells in a hybrid PMMA/PDMS microdevice

finding: It was mentioned as being solely associated with TN disease in case-case comparisons and confirmed as strongly associated with TN status.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Found associated with TN disease, being confirmed in case-case analyses with TN status.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: This variant had an OR of 1.44 (95% CI 1.40 to 1.48, p=2.26×10^-131), indicating a strong association with risk of luminal A-like disease.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: It showed an OR of 1.33 (95% CI 1.30 to 1.37, p=1.31×10^-98) for risk of luminal A-like disease.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: Showed strong evidence for predisposing to high-grade tumor subtypes.
title: Common variants in breast cancer risk loci predispose to distinct tumor subtypes

finding: The rs3736228 polymorphism (Ala/Val) at residue 1330 in LRP5 was found to have clinical significance as homozygous Val variants, which are present in less than 5% of the population, were associated with increased joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis patients. This polymorphism also showed that LDLa repeats containing the Val residue exhibited reduced binding to EPA compared to repeats with the Ala residue, suggesting potential impacts on PUFA accretion and associated phenotypes.
title: LDL Receptor-Related Protein 5 is a Selective Transporter for Unesterified Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids

finding: The variant rs2727271 displayed an allelic skew effect by MPRA, increasing activity by 1.2 log2 fold and overlapping with an HCR-FlowFISH validated CRE for both FADS1 and FADS2, indicating its involvement in regulating these genes.
title: HCR-FlowFISH: A flexible CRISPR screening method to identify cis-regulatory elements and their target genes

finding: The variant rs174466 was shown to be the only one that conveys both allelic skew by MPRA and validity as a CRE by HCR-FlowFISH. This variant acted on FADS3 and was linked to a transcriptional activator, suggesting it enhances FADS3 expression through its regulatory potential.
title: HCR-FlowFISH: A flexible CRISPR screening method to identify cis-regulatory elements and their target genes

finding: The rs61909476 variant was associated with fasting glucose (FG) in African American individuals, showing an effect size of β=0.0812 mmol/l (P=3.9×10^-8) while no significant effect was seen in European individuals (β=0.0015 mmol/l, P=0.44). This SNP is near the ETS1 gene, which encodes a transcription factor associated with insulin secretion.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The rs10830963 SNP located in an intron of the MTNR1B gene showed strong associations with both HbA1c and fasting glucose (FG), indicating allelic differences in enhancer activity and transcription factor binding, demonstrating its important role in glycaemic traits.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The rs617948 variant was associated with HbA1c levels and expression of C2CD2L, indicating its influence on insulin secretion and glycaemic control.
title: The Trans-Ancestral Genomic Architecture of Glycaemic Traits

finding: The rs35705950 SNP was confirmed to be a significant risk factor for IPF, with an additive effect observed in both discovery and validation cohorts, demonstrating strong associations with increased risk of developing the disease.
title: Toll-Like-Receptor 5 protects against pulmonary fibrosis by reducing lung dysbiosis

finding: The SNP rs1695, associated with the mHA DLRCKYISL from the gene GSTP1, was linked to an increased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) mortality, presenting a hazard ratio (HR) of 2.84 with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of [1.52, 5.31], and a P-value of 0.01 in patients with the HLA-B*08:01 allele.
title: Associations of Minor Histocompatibility Antigens with Clinical Outcomes Following Allogeneic Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation

finding: This novel locus showed pathogenic scores and had eQTL relevance in various tissues.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: Associated with BMI, this SNP had significant posterior probabilities in credible sets.
title: Ancestral diversity improves discovery and fine-mapping of genetic loci for anthropometric traits - the Hispanic/Latino Anthropometry Consortium

finding: The rs79423518-tagged CRE was associated with significant regulatory effects on the expressions of both PRDX5 and TRMT112. This was validated through CRISPRi screening and RT-qPCR results, which indicated that sgRNAs targeting rs79423518 significantly decreased the expression of these genes.
title: Endogenous fine-mapping of functional regulatory elements in complex genetic loci

finding: Similar to rs79423518, the rs4930698-tagged CRE regulated the expression of PRDX5 and TRMT112. Evidence from RT-qPCR confirmed this regulatory effect which was observed through multiplexed CRISPR perturbations.
title: Endogenous fine-mapping of functional regulatory elements in complex genetic loci

finding: The SNP rs35705950 in MUC5B was associated with a significant odds ratio of 5.64 for incidence in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. In the survival analysis, it showed a paradoxical association of increased survival with a hazard ratio of 0.766, prompting further investigation into index event bias. An empirical analysis suggested a positive log hazard ratio, indicating a potentially strong effect on survival.
title: Adjustment for index event bias in genome-wide association studies of subsequent events

finding: This variant located in the TYR gene was acknowledged as an independent locus associated with eye colour, demonstrating significant effects despite being one of several SNPs linked to pigmentation.
title: Investigating the genetic architecture of eye colour in a Canadian cohort

finding: The SNP rs36051450, located near GGRAMD1B, was associated with a p-value of 2e-9, indicating a significant reduction in the hazards of Alzheimer's disease (AD) across both genders. This finding was substantial, as the SNP's effect was stronger than results from logistic mixed effects models that yielded a p-value of only 2.85e-05, suggesting the SNP might be more influential on disease progression than incidence.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of age-at-onset traits using Cox mixed-effects models

finding: The variant rs63750205 in the 3' UTR of HBB was identified as likely pathogenic for beta Thalassemia. In the XBI cohort, this variant was associated with a reduction in mean corpuscular volume by 2.88 standard deviations (s.d.).
title: The sequences of 150,119 genomes in the UK biobank

finding: The 'CC' genotype for rs2292912/CRY2 negatively influenced language and executive function. Its association with language and memory impairments was noted, marking it as a potential genetic risk factor for PSCI.
title: Genetic Variations and Altered Blood mRNA Level of Circadian Genes and BDNF as Risk Factors of Post-Stroke Cognitive Impairment among Eastern Indians

finding: The Ser159Gly (G) missense variant associated with greater IL10 levels measured on the Olink platform (effect=0.26 SD; p=3.6×10-194) and higher IL10RA levels (effect=0.19 SD; p=1.2×10-93), confirming its role in monogenic IBD, with an increased risk of IBD in a meta-analysis (OR=1.05, p=1.6×10-5).
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: This sentinel cis pQTL was in high LD (r²=1) with the colorectal cancer risk variant (rs4944940) and confirmed previous findings of association with colorectal cancer risk.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: This variant was the disease associated variant in high LD with rs11236228, providing independent replication for colorectal cancer findings.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: The SNP rs79761481 was identified as a potential genetic biomarker associated with Parkinson's Disease (PD) during GWAS analyses. This variant was significantly linked to differences in DaTscan values between healthy individuals and those with PD, indicating its relevance in understanding the genetic underpinnings of PD. Notably, rs79761481 was located within the CD6 gene, which is part of the CD genes family that has previously been associated with the onset of PD at the immune system level.
title: Multi view based imaging genetics analysis on Parkinson disease

finding: Near the TNKS1BP1 gene (11q12.1), rs12787728 showed associations with both HDL and total cholesterol.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs662799 in the APOA5-APOC3 locus was positively associated with certain lipid changes linked to cardiovascular disease risk. Specifically, lipids TG 53:3 and TG 56:4, which are correlated with rs662799, were found to be associated with risk factors including hypertension and diabetes according to data from the PROMIS case-control study.
title: Allergic inflammation triggers dyslipidemia via IgG signalling

finding: The rs33930165 variant within exon 1 of HBB was identified as a pathogenic variant associated with sickle cell disease. Over 90% of sickle cell disease cases were reported to be either HbSS or HbSC, indicating the significant role of this variant in the phenotype.
title: A novel high-throughput molecular counting method with single base-pair resolution enables accurate single-gene NIPT

finding: The rs713040 variant in HBB exon 1 was utilized to detect paternal inheritance in cases with heterozygous maternal genotypes during NIPT analyses. The findings indicated that allele fractions from maternal blood samples correctly reflected fetal genotypes, supporting the efficacy of NIPT in assessing recessive disorders and achieving 100% concordance with newborn follow-ups.
title: A novel high-throughput molecular counting method with single base-pair resolution enables accurate single-gene NIPT

finding: The rs12252-C polymorphism was reported to express an N-terminally truncated IFITM3 and was significantly associated with the severity of COVID-19. This finding indicated that the presence of this variant may influence the susceptibility to more severe outcomes of the disease by affecting the function of the IFITM protein family involved in regulating viral entry and innate immune responses.
title: The polybasic cleavage site in the SARS-CoV-2 spike modulates viral sensitivity to Type I IFN and IFITM2

finding: The Taq1A SNP (rs1800497) genotype was likewise linked to behavioral control, with the presence of the A1+ allele correlating with changes in striatal dopamine function and influencing decision-making processes. This SNP was pivotal in categorizing subjects based on their dopaminergic profile and its effects on rule-based task performance, suggesting that variations in this genetic locus played a significant role in modulating behaviors related to goal-directed tasks.
title: A dopaminergic basis of behavioral control

finding: This gain-of-function variant was found to create an upstream CFIm-binding motif (TGTA) and was associated with significantly higher variant fold changes compared to other TGTA- or GT-creating mutations, as supported by the MPRA data. It was associated with cooperative interactions with downstream T-rich motifs, enhancing its variant effects.
title: Deciphering the Impact of Genetic Variation on Human Polyadenylation

finding: The analysis indicated that SNP rs3842753 was associated with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). This SNP was among the ten most highly activated SNPs in the GLN model, confirming previous findings that linked it to T1D and showcasing the model's capability to identify a range of associated SNPs for specific diseases.
title: Deep integrative models for large-scale human genomics

finding: The SNP rs2019090, located on Chromosome 11, was identified as a lead SNP associated with cIMT and showed evidence of eQTL effects in aorta tissue, linking it to gene expression relevant to cardiovascular health.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: SNP rs11025608 was identified as a lead SNP associated with IMTmax, and its effects were consistent with those for IMTmean, demonstrating its relevance in vascular remodeling research.
title: Carotid intima-media thickness in UK Biobank: Identification of novel genome-wide loci, sex-specific effects and genetic correlations with obesity and glucometabolic traits

finding: This SNP was associated with abnormal glucose metabolism and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) specifically in Japanese populations, highlighting its significance in metabolic studies.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: Located in the ZPR1 gene, this SNP was identified as associated with dyslipidemia, indicating its relevance to lipid metabolism disorders.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: This mutation was analyzed in the context of its pathogenicity, where it was found to have conflicting classifications regarding its role, initially deemed benign but later categorized as harmful.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The I196T mutation was recognized as harmful based on SIFT and PolyPhen-2 assessments, marking it as a significant finding linked to a rare ZPR1 disorder.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: This SNP was associated with plasma triglyceride levels and identified as pathogenic in the study, despite having the highest minor allele frequency at 0.0658 among analyzed mutations.
title: Bioinformatic analysis of human ZPR1 gene pathogenic exome mutations

finding: The SNP rs11030293 was found to be positively related to the PI3K signaling pathway activity in research presented by van de Stolpe (2019). This association highlighted the role of this SNP in the regulation of the PI3K pathway, which is critical in various cellular processes, including stem cell differentiation and cancer progression.
title: Measurement of activity of developmental signal transduction pathways to quantify stem cell pluripotency and phenotypically characterize differentiated cells

finding: The SNP rs2618516 was linked to the protein apolipoprotein E (APOE), known for its involvement in fat metabolism. The presence of the APOE4 allele was associated with increased risk of Late-Onset Alzheimer's Disease (LOAD), while APOE2 showed protective effects, indicating its relevance in the cognitive health of elderly caregivers.
title: Evolution of Human-specific Alleles Protecting Cognitive Function of Grandmothers

finding: SNP rs1552726 was associated with gene NLRP14. It was determined that this SNP may affect splice site activity and is relevant to spermatogenic failure, having been noted in the context of various mutations identified in patients.
title: Locating suspicious lethal genes by abnormal distributions of SNP patterns

finding: The clQTL rs546512774 was validated within the ARNTL locus, showing expected directionalities in chromatin accessibility and TCF21 binding in association with CAD risk.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The bQTL rs1037169 was confirmed to regulate TCF21 binding and chromatin accessibility at the ARNTL locus, contributing to the understanding of its role in CAD.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapped for TCF21 binding, chromatin accessibility and chromosomal looping in coronary artery smooth muscle cells reveal molecular mechanisms of coronary disease loci

finding: The SNP rs964184, located on the 3' UTR of the ZPR1 gene on chromosome 11, was associated with triglyceride levels (trait ID: TG) and exhibited a significant difference in allele frequency between THC Jomon ancestry and THC modern Japanese/THC continental ancestry. Specifically, the allele frequencies were 94% in Jomon ancestry, 28% in modern Japanese, and 18% in continental ancestry. This SNP significantly increased triglyceride levels (β = 0.16, P = 1.4 x 10^-272), highlighting the phenotypic adaptation of the Jomon people who likely needed to maintain high triglyceride levels in their hunter-gatherer lifestyle.
title: Modern Japanese ancestry-derived variants revealed the formation process of the current Japanese regional gradations

finding: The SNP rs12218 was associated with myocardial infarction in a Chinese population, indicating its potential role in cardiovascular health.
title: Identification of novel key genes and signaling pathways in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The IFN-γ +874 (rs2406918) CC genotype also seemed to serve as a protective marker against BKV infection, reinforcing the concept that IFN-γ gene polymorphisms might influence susceptibility or protection related to BKV infection.
title: The change of lymphocyte subsets and inflammatory cytokine in BK viruria

finding: The G allele of the UTR variant rs5128 was associated with plasma triglyceride levels in the Taiwanese population, highlighting the variant's role in influencing RNA and protein expression relevant to health biomarkers.
title: Multiplexed Assays of Human Disease-relevant Mutations Reveal UTR Dinucleotide Composition as a Major Determinant of RNA Stability

finding: SNP rs1187159 was identified as a distinct risk locus and achieved replication in the ENIGMA dataset, with a significant two-tailed binomial test result (P = 6.25 × 10−30).
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs2845871 was noted for its high CADD score indicating potential deleterious effects, and like the others, it was among those associated with volumetric imaging derived phenotypes.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide analyses of the brain imaging phenotypes in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs10891314 was highlighted as a genome-wide significant hit, being linked to the gene DLAT. This missense variant exhibited a high conservation score and was associated with Pyruvate Dehydrogenase E2 deficiency, a rare neurodevelopmental disorder leading to neurological dysfunction and learning disabilities in childhood. The finding underscored its potential role in increasing susceptibility to rhythm impairment and dyslexia.
title: The shared genetic architecture and evolution of human language and musical rhythm

finding: The SNP rs1815739, associated with the nonsense polymorphism in the ACTN3 gene, was identified as having significant implications regarding athletic performance and cold tolerance. Specifically, individuals homozygous for the X-allele (ACTN3 577XX) lacked the fast muscle fiber protein alpha-actinin-3, which led to a detrimental effect on sprint performance in elite athletes. However, this genotypic configuration improved cold tolerance as evidenced by increased slow myosin heavy chain muscle fibers in XX individuals, resulting in enhanced muscle tone and fatigue resistance. The age of the x-allele was estimated at approximately 135,000 years, showing an increased prevalence in European and Asian populations roughly 42,000 years ago, suggesting selection for this variant in response to environmental factors.
title: α-Actinin-3 deficiency protects from the effects of acute cold exposure through altered skeletal muscle Ca2+ and OXPHOS signaling

finding: The splice region variant rs1806152 was associated with the expression of the nearby gene PAX6 Upstream Antisense RNA (PAUPAR) on chromosome 11 as part of the fine-mapping effort.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of major depression aids locus discovery, fine-mapping, gene prioritisation, and causal inference

finding: The SNP rs2237892 was maternally associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) across several cohorts, including findings from an Iceland cohort and a Pima Amerindian cohort. This SNP was identified as a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C, confirming its role downstream of KCNQ1.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: Similar to rs2237892, the SNP rs2283228 was found to be a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C. It was significantly associated with T2D in various cohorts and was consistent with the expression regulation observed in the eQTL analysis.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: This SNP was also identified as a maternal eQTL of CDKN1C. With confirmed associations with T2D in Japanese and subsequent cohorts, it added to the evidence showing its relevance in the genetic landscape of T2D.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: rs2237897 was shown to be a maternal eQTL for CDKN1C as well. Like rs2237892 and rs2237895, it was involved in the associations found in T2D studies across multiple cohorts.
title: Abundant Parent-of-origin Effect eQTL in Humans: The Framingham Heart Study

finding: The sentinel SNP rs78176967 was significantly associated with androsterone glucuronide levels (p-values ranging from 1×10^-55 to 9×10^-11), highlighting its potential role in steroid metabolism.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: Similar to rs78176967, rs151042642 was also identified as a sentinel SNP significantly associated with androsterone glucuronide levels (p-values ranging from 1×10^-55 to 9×10^-11).
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: The nonsense variant rs11231341, encoding p.Tyr501Ter, was associated with lower levels of both androsterone glucuronide and etiocholanolone glucuronide (p<5×10^-8), illustrating its influence on steroid metabolism.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: The splice donor variant rs1939749 affected splicing in SLC22A24 and was associated with lower expression levels of SLC22A24 in kidney eQTL studies, suggesting its critical role in the regulation of steroid metabolism.
title: Unraveling the functional role of the orphan solute carrier, SLC22A24 in the transport of steroid conjugates through metabolomic and genome-wide association studies

finding: The SNP rs11040528 was associated with the role of HOX transcription factors, including HOXB7, in cancer predisposition and progression. It was noted that amplification and overexpression of HOXB7 correlated with poor prognosis in breast cancer, suggesting that genetic variations such as rs11040528 could influence cancer outcomes.
title: HOXB7 induces STAT3-mediated transformation and lung metastasis in an immortalized mammary gland NMuMG cells

finding: The SNP rs11020136 was identified as a positive and original finding in the context of extracellular vesicles (EVs) related to cellular stress response. It was linked to the modulation of EV cargo under conditions of DNA damage response (DDR) induced by UV-C radiation. Although sEVs expression was stable, the altered composition in sEVs from irradiated iPSC-MSC indicated a specific change in their protein content associated with impaired migration in target cells, thus suggesting a significant role for this SNP in understanding the biology of cancer therapy resistance as described in the referenced work.
title: Small extracellular vesicles from iPSC-MSC lose their regenerative potential upon UV-C irradiation

finding: The rs35705950 SNP was identified as being associated with an enhancer that is subject to lineage-and disease-dependent epigenetic remodeling. This finding suggested a role of the MUC5B-associated variant in respiratory diseases, particularly in the context of deployment-related respiratory diseases (DRRD), implicating it in the pathobiology of diseases linked to exposure to airborne particulates.
title: Integrated Genomics Approaches Identify Transcriptional Mediators and Epigenetic Responses to Afghan Desert Particulate Matter in Small Airway Epithelial Cells

finding: The SNP rs610932 was linked with Alzheimer's disease, indicating the importance of transcription factors in neurodegenerative pathways.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: Selection at FADS1 (rs174546) indicated a strong signal of adaptation related to fatty acid metabolism, which supported dietary changes from vegetarian to more carnivorous diets during the Neolithic era.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: FADS2 (rs174581) also showed strong signals of selection tied to dietary changes, suggesting that the adaptive landscape for fatty acid metabolism shifted during the transition to agriculture.
title: Population Genomics of Stone Age Eurasia

finding: The SNP rs11040461 was associated with altered NK cell phenotype, specifically the acquisition of a CD56brightCD9+CD49a+CXCR4+ phenotype in prostate cancer patients. This finding was considered original as it was the first report indicating the pro-inflammatory characteristics associated with this SNP in the context of PCa.
title: Prostate cancer peripheral blood NK cells show enhanced CD9, CD49a, CXCR4, CXCL8, MMP-9 production, and secrete monocyte-recruiting and polarizing factors

finding: The rs1004446 SNP had a PVS of 0.51 and fell under L2 pleiotropy class. Its associated phenotypes included type 1 diabetes mellitus and multiple sclerosis.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The rs964184 SNP exhibited high pleiotropy with a PVS of 0.565, associated with more than 45 distinct disease, phenotype, or trait associations.
title: Pleiotropic Variability Score: A Genome Interpretation Metric to Quantify Phenomic Associations of Genomic Variants

finding: The SNP rs2618516 was identified in the SPON1 gene as a genetic variant associated with dementia subjects using connectivity patterns as a phenotype in a prior study. This finding contributed to understanding genetic factors in neurodegenerative disorders.
title: Genome-Wide Association Study of Brain Connectivity Changes for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs933920 was identified as an intronic variant in the PARVA gene at the 11p15.2-3 locus with a P-value of 0.0036. This finding highlighted the potential interplay between local ancestry and smoking on pulmonary function.
title: Mixed-model admixture mapping identifies smoking-dependent loci of lung function in African Americans

finding: The SNP rs484915 was identified as a genome-wide significant cis-acting pQTL variant on chromosome 11, with a P value of 1.81×10−8. It was significantly associated with the production of MMP-1 protein concentrations and also showed association with gene expression levels specifically in monocytes upon stimulation with Candida albicans.
title: Integration of Candida albicans-induced single-cell gene expression data and circulatory protein concentrations reveal genetic regulators of inflammation

finding: The SNP rs7116008 was an intronic variant in the ST3GAL4 gene and exhibited the most significant association with platelet count (PLT) among GP5 protein quantitative trait locus (pQTLs). This association was suggested to be mediated by the effect of ST3GAL4 on the desialyation of GP5, impacting its clearance from circulation.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: The instrumental variable SNP rs11217234 was nominally associated with a decreased risk of a second myocardial infarction event. Although MCAM was causally associated with decreased PLT, this was not supported by gene silencing experiments in iPSC MK.
title: Integrative Genomic Analysis and Functional Studies Reveal GP5, GRN, MPO and MCAM as Causal Protein Biomarkers for Platelet Traits

finding: The haplotype pair of rs11020521 and rs11020522 presented interaction effects that included a sign reversal, where both variants had no effect or weakly positive impacts individually, but the joint haplotype yielded a much stronger effect in the opposite direction.
title: Multiple Causal Variants Underlie Genetic Associations in Humans

finding: As with rs11020521, this SNP was involved in the haplotype interaction that demonstrated a significant effect, providing evidence of non-additive effects and sign reversal when considered in conjunction with rs11020521.
title: Multiple Causal Variants Underlie Genetic Associations in Humans

finding: The SNP rs2305498, an intronic variant at the TPCN2 locus, was associated with increased waist-hip ratio adjusted for body mass index (WHRadjBMI) specifically in females (beta = 0.0208, p=6.06E-11). This association indicated a link between the variant and fat distribution, with the signal correlating with reduced TPCN2 expression in subcutaneous adipose tissue.
title: Two-pore channel 2 is a key regulator of adipocyte differentiation via the cAMP signaling pathway with calpain as downstream effector

finding: The genetic variant rs12252-C of the Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) was found to be associated with increased disease severity in COVID-19, as reported in multiple studies, including a 2020 study that linked it to a higher COVID-19 mortality rate.
title: Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) limits lethality of SARS-CoV-2 in mice

finding: The rs34481144 variant, when combined with rs12252 within the same haplotype, was correlated with the COVID-19 standardized mortality ratio in ethnic groups in a 2020 study, establishing its relevance to the severity of COVID-19.
title: Interferon-induced transmembrane protein 3 (IFITM3) limits lethality of SARS-CoV-2 in mice

finding: The index SNP rs74685827 was reported to overlap with a microglia-specific cCRE linked to dysregulated SORL1 gene expression in the hippocampus. Its associated SNP, rs1591330048, was also identified to overlap with a cCRE linked to dysregulated SORL1 gene expression in astrocytes within the same brain region.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: This SNP was associated with a cCRE linked to SORL1 dysregulation in astrocytes in the hippocampus, emphasizing its involvement in cellular dysregulation associated with sEOAD.
title: Single-nucleus multiomics reveals the disrupted regulatory programs in three brain regions of sporadic early-onset Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The Val66Met SNP (rs6265), located in the gene coding for brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), was associated with a reduction in recognition memory performance. It influenced the subprocesses of recognition memory by reducing accuracy on the familiarity measure, while no group differences were found in recollection accuracy. The findings suggested functional influences of the SNP on recognition memory that were independent of structural changes in grey and white matter.
title: The Brain-Derived Neurotrophic Factor Val66Met Genotype Does Not Influence the Grey or White Matter Structures Underlying Recognition Memory

finding: The common intronic low spinal BMD-associated variant rs599083 was associated with an increased android-to-leg fat ratio, illustrating its impact on fat distribution. This finding was confirmed using a genome wide association study meta-analysis and linked to its role as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for LRP5 in lower leg skin. The context of this finding was significant, as it suggested how genetic variation could influence fat distribution in relation to bone mineral density.
title: LRP5 promotes adipose progenitor cell fitness and adipocyte insulin sensitivity

finding: The SNP rs7944926 was associated with the DHCR7 gene, which provides protection against vitamin D insufficiency. It was under significant selection in Britain, with the selection coefficient increasing from around 0 to 0.06 over the past 150 generations, leading to an increase in allele frequency from approximately 20% to 60% over the past 3000 years.
title: Direct detection of natural selection in Bronze Age Britain

finding: The rs2526678 variant associated with 1,2-dillnoleoyl-GPC was linked to <italic>FADS2</italic>, reinforcing existing knowledge.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The SNP rs17602038 associated with DRD2 was discovered to be genome-wide significant for smoking cessation, corroborated by earlier findings.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The SNP rs6589386 near DRD2 was recognized as a genome-wide significant locus for smoking initiation, also identified as colocalized with AUD traits.
title: Multi-trait genome-wide association analyses leveraging alcohol use disorder findings identify novel loci for smoking behaviors in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The rs17224476 variant, identified as associated with diastolic blood pressure (DBP) in previous studies, showed that each copy of the minor allele A increased DBP by approximately 0.16 mmHg (p=7.37 × 10−9) in the UK Biobank analysis. This association held across all individuals, indicating no significant difference between sexes.
title: An evolutionarily conserved olfactory receptor is required for sex differences in blood pressure

finding: The rs202113356 rare variant exhibited a significant sex interaction effect (p=0.0148), where it decreased DBP in men but increased DBP by approximately +6.28 mmHg in women carriers (AG) compared to non-carrier females (GG), with a nominal significance in females (p=0.053). In younger women under 50 years, the association was stronger at p=0.0501, revealing an even larger effect size (+13.44 mmHg).
title: An evolutionarily conserved olfactory receptor is required for sex differences in blood pressure

finding: This SNP was reported to be associated with drinking behavior, contributing to the understanding of genetic influences on problematic alcohol use.
